# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 171, 196, 202]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 221, 170, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 214, 428, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 214, 907, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 277, 232, 294]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 278, 907, 293]]<|/det|>
9709/53  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 303, 341, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Probability & Statistics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 907, 319]]<|/det|>
October/November 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 419, 225, 435]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 217, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Becky sometimes works in an office and sometimes works at home. The random variable \(X\) denotes the number of days that she works at home in any given week. It is given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 114, 584, 133]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{P}(X = x) = k x(x + 1),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 140, 494, 160]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant and \(x = 1\), 2, 3 or 4 only.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 172, 148, 191]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 170, 915, 191]]<|/det|>
Draw up the probability distribution table for \(X\), giving the probabilities as numerical fractions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 188, 920, 207]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 530, 185, 548]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 529, 343, 548]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{E}(X)\) and \(\mathrm{Var}(X)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 529, 920, 548]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The weights of large bags of pasta produced by a company are normally distributed with mean \(1.5\mathrm{kg}\) and standard deviation \(0.05\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that a randomly chosen large bag of pasta weighs between \(1.42\mathrm{kg}\) and \(1.52\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 504, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
The weights of small bags of pasta produced by the company are normally distributed with mean \(0.75\mathrm{kg}\) and standard deviation \(\sigma \mathrm{kg}\). It is found that \(68\%\) of these small bags have weight less than \(0.9\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 571, 146, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 571, 316, 588]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\sigma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 570, 920, 588]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 430, 92]]<|/det|>
Tim has two bags of marbles, \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 104, 574, 123]]<|/det|>
Bag \(A\) contains 8 white, 4 red and 3 yellow marbles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 127, 574, 145]]<|/det|>
Bag \(B\) contains 6 white, 7 red and 2 yellow marbles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 158, 920, 207]]<|/det|>
Tim also has an ordinary fair 6-sided dice. He rolls the dice. If he obtains a 1 or 2, he chooses two marbles at random from bag \(A\), without replacement. If he obtains a 3, 4, 5 or 6, he chooses two marbles at random from bag \(B\), without replacement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 220, 146, 238]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 220, 544, 238]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that both marbles are white.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 220, 920, 238]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the two marbles come from bag \(B\) given that one is white and one is red.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 88, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Calculate estimates for the mean and standard deviation of the weights of the 120 students. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 823, 92]]<|/det|>
The probability that a driver passes an advanced driving test is 0.3 on any given attempt.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Dipak keeps taking the test until he passes. The random variable \(X\) denotes the number of attempts required for Dipak to pass the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 145, 195, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 144, 351, 163]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(2 \leqslant X \leqslant 6)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 413, 186, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 413, 288, 432]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{E}(X)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 413, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 556, 636, 575]]<|/det|>
Five friends will each take their advanced driving test tomorrow.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 588, 148, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 588, 688, 606]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that at least three of them will pass tomorrow.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 588, 920, 606]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
For a competition during the party, the 12 people are divided at random into a group of 5, a group of 4 and a group of 3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 740, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Jai and Kaz are in the same group as each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 75, 569, 92]]<|/det|>
